$psql -c 'create database simplekv_test;' -U postgres

	connections on Unix domain socket "/var/run/postgresql/.s.PGSQL.5432"?

Here the link: https://travis-ci.org/mbr/simplekv/jobs/599538462

items.title: Wrong return type of FilesystemStore method 'keys'
items.body: According to docs, the `.keys` method of a store should return a value of type `list` and not any iterable (this is what iter_keys is for). However, the `FilesystemStore.keys` method returns a generator in python 3, as it uses the builting `filter`.

items.title: Add 'delimiter' keyword to 'iter_keys'
items.body:
I would like to use the feature that one can give the keyword `delimiter` to the `store.iter_keys` method (https://github.com/mbr/simplekv/blob/master/simplekv/__init__.py#L102).

Some implementations support this feature:
- azure: https://github.com/Azure/azure-storage-python/blob/master/azure-storage-blob/azure/storage/blob/baseblobservice.py#L1202
- boto: https://github.com/boto/boto/blob/develop/boto/s3/bucket.py#L234

Others would allow an implementation for it:
- redis: Allows pattern (https://redis.io/commands/keys, https://github.com/andymccurdy/redis-py/blob/master/redis/client.py#L1260)

For remaining stores one could implement a slow evaluation which iterates over all existing keys.

Are there opinions on this? I would welcome a short discussion about this feature. I am also willing to implement some stuff (don't know how good I can implement the feature for the `db` stores).

items.title: _put_file unimplemented even though _put calls it
items.body:
```
    def _put(self, key, data):
        """Implementation for :meth:`~simplekv.KeyValueStore.put`. The default
        implementation will create a :class:`io.BytesIO`-buffer and then call
        :meth:`~simplekv.KeyValueStore._put_file`.

        :param key: Key under which data should be stored
        :param data: Data to be stored
        """
        return self._put_file(key, BytesIO(data))

    def _put_file(self, key, file):
        """Store data from file-like object in key. Either this method or
        :meth:`~simplekv.KeyValueStore._put_filename` will be called by
        :meth:`~simplekv.KeyValueStore.put_file`. Note that this method does
        not accept strings.

        The default implementation will simply raise a
        :py:exc:`~exceptions.NotImplementedError`.

        :param key: Key under which data should be stored
        :param file: File-like object to store data from
        """
        raise NotImplementedError
```

JWT requires a simplekv KeyValueStore if you're using the blacklist feature. However, when it tries to use the simplekv features, it calls _put(something) which calls _put_file(something) and that raises a Not Implemented Error. 

```
        self._flask_app.config['JWT_BLACKLIST_ENABLED'] = True
        self._flask_app.config['JWT_BLACKLIST_STORE'] = simplekv.KeyValueStore()
```

items.title: AzureException always raised as KeyError
items.body:
Hi,
when trying to put a file to an azure blob storage

`store.put_file('myfile.txt','myfile.txt')`

this confusing KeyError was returned:
`  File "...lib/python2.7/site-packages/simplekv/__init__.py", line 177, in put_file
    return self._put_filename(key, file)
  File "...lib/python2.7/site-packages/simplekv/net/azurestore.py", line 123, in _put_filename
    return key
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/contextlib.py", line 35, in __exit__
    self.gen.throw(type, value, traceback)
  File "...lib/python2.7/site-packages/simplekv/net/azurestore.py", line 38, in map_azure_exceptions
    raise KeyError(key)
KeyError: 'myfile.txt' `

In this case the cause was a missing internet connecting. Could you please consider to improve the exception handling and not raise all AzureException as KeyError.

items.title: PyPi package is outdated
items.body: The PyPi package looks outdated. When I try using it with Python 3, it fails because the `BotoStore.py` file still tries to use `from itertools import imap` instead of using `_compat`.

items.title: Broken Documentation Link
items.body: http://pythonhosted.org/simplekv is a broken link, but is referenced as documentation in the README.

items.title: Discussion: Drop the memcache backend
items.body:
Hi,
I propose dropping the memcache backend for several reasons:
- Simplekv provides by definition only a simple set of instructions. Memcache can not even implement like half of these
- Screws with the tests of other features, because tests have to be adjusted in case they dare to use a feature not present in the memcache backend, they will fail
- Other, more capable backends available

In case you use the memcache backend, please let us know and give your input!

items.title: Blue Yonder simplekv development effort
items.body:
Hi,
we at Blue Yonder use simplekv a lot.
We love that it is easily possible to use a filesystem-backed store during development and replace that by using a S3-backed store for production, and maybe adding, without hassle, a redis cache in front of the data store. And all without touching the application code!
To further our relationship with simplekv, we’d love to help out with the development and put effort into making simplekv even better.

We want to work on the following things:
- Merging the open pull requests from @fmarczin and @Corni
- Developing a high-quality Azure Blob Storage backend. We know that the code in the current pull request is not on par quality-wise with the existing code base, so we will work on that.
Allowing slashes and spaces in key names. We have several applications where this is unfortunately unavoidable, as well as full support for all backends in our patch.
- Discuss dropping the memcache backend - a backend which does not support like half the operations, can’t fake them either and just raises exceptions instead is in my opinion not useful.
- We currently have code internally which takes an ini file or an URL and turns that into a simplekv store instance. We would like to either open source that project by itself, or, preferably, include the code in simplekv.

If we are on the same page with these goals, we would love if you could consider granting @fmarczin and maybe me commit access to the project.
We remain committed to the idea that a simple, basic API which does not everything and which does not expose or emulate hierarchical structures is a great fit for many projects.

Regards,
Cornelius

items.title: Table already defined on this metadata instance
items.body:
I am using kvsession in a flask app and it works as expected. I ran into this while running tests:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/user/project/tests/base.py", line 20, in setUpClass
    cls.app = get_app('testing')
  File "/home/user/project/__init__.py", line 30, in get_app
    session_store = SQLAlchemyStore(engine, db.Model.metadata, 'kvsession')
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/simplekv/db/sql.py", line 21, in __init__
    Column('value', LargeBinary, nullable=False)
  File "/home/user/.virtualenvs/project/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/sql/schema.py", line 398, in __new__
    "existing Table object." % key)
InvalidRequestError: Table 'kvsession' is already defined for this MetaData instance.  Specify 'extend_existing=True' to redefine options and columns on an existing Table object.
```

It somehow happens because the tests call the initialization twice. I could not work around this, any ideas?

items.title: Allow "/" in keys
items.body:
I was wondering what your opinion is on allowing / in keys.

The rationale behind it is that most if not all backends allow it, and some backends like S3 ([AWS docs](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingMetadata.html)) and file systems handle this in a way that makes the keyspace much more organized.

I would see this purely as a change in some backends, and it's not supposed to affect the API semantics to make it in any way (pseudo-)hierarchical.

If you think this has merit, I would come up with a PR.

items.title: simplekv doesn't come up in search on pypi
items.body:
No idea if this is technically an issue in simplekv, but I though it's worth reporting:

While simplekv is on pypi (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/simplekv/0.9.3), and it does appear in the list of packages (https://pypi.python.org/pypi?%3Aaction=index), the package is not listed when I search for "simplekv" , "key value storage" or "key-value". Weirdly, a search for "simplekv" does return two hits: Flask-KVSession and legitfs, which both mention simplekv in their README.

items.title: PrefixDecorator fails with non-prefixed keys
items.body:
If the "parent" store of a PrefixDecorator contains non-prefixed keys, the prefixed store fails when it sees those keys, e.g. when listing keys.

Example:

```
s1 = FilesystemStore('./store')
s2 = PrefixDecorator('pre-', s1)
s1.put('foo', 'val')
s2.put('bar', 'val')
print(s1.keys())  # -> outputs ['foo', 'pre-bar']
print(s2.keys())  # expected: ['bar'], but fails with AssertionError
```

This is not completely trivial to fix, since KeyTransformingDecorator currently doesn't expect the transformation to change the number of keys, which I think is the expected behaviour here (s2.keys() only returning the one key).

I have a fix for both issues ready, so it would be great to know if you think you can use that.

items.title: How to use memcache with simplekv?
items.body:
I am trying to use memcache with simplekv, But as mentioned in the documentation, I get an IO error when I  try to clear the cache.

from simplekv.memory.memcachestore import MemcacheStore
import memcache
import redis
import datetime
# store = RedisStore(redis.StrictRedis())

store = MemcacheStore(memcache.Client(['127.0.0.1:11211'], debug = 0))
store.ttl_support = True
app = create_app(**name**)
current_kvsession = KVSessionExtension(store, app)
for key in app.kvsession_store.keys():
        logger.debug(key)
        m = current_kvsession.key_regex.match(key)
        logger.debug('found %s', m)
        logger.debug(app.kvsession_store.delete(key))

Since memcache doesn`t support  app.kvsession_store.keys(). Do I need to remember the key somewhere so that I won`t have to pull it out of memcache? Let me know if more explaination is needed.

Hi Marc, it's Serge, your favourite linux arch packager ;-)

items.title: setup.py should mention Python 3 support
items.body:
This is helpful for CLI tools like "caniusepython3". I erroneously thought simplekv didn't have python 3 support because of that. 
Fixing this is easy. In setup.py:

```
    classifiers=[
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 2',
        'Programming Language :: Python :: 3',
    ],
```

items.title: Float TTL does not work with memcached pylibmc
items.body:
Hi,

I was moving some project from a test scenario to use simplekv with memcache and pylibmc. SimpleKV tries to intercept bad ttl values by checking for [int, float] but in any case, the call to pylibmc `set`will result in an error if  float value is used.

Sample code follows:

``` python
import pylibmc
from simplekv.memory import memcachestore

mc = pylibmc.Client(["127.0.0.1"], binary=True, behaviors={"tcp_nodelay": True, "ketama": True})
store = memcachestore.MemcacheStore(mc)
store.put("the_key", "the_data", ttl_secs=3.4)
```

The result is:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "prueba.py", line 6, in <module>
    store.put("the_key", "the_data", ttl_secs=3.4)
  File "/Users/fdelgado/dev/Bouncer/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/simplekv/__init__.py", line 374, in put
    return self._put(key, data, self._valid_ttl(ttl_secs))
  File "/Users/fdelgado/dev/Bouncer/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/simplekv/memory/memcachestore.py", line 53, in _put
    if not self.mc.set(key.encode('ascii'), data, time=time):
TypeError: integer argument expected, got float
```

The libs used are:
- simplekv==0.9.2
- pylibmc==1.4.1

against memcache 1.4.14.

I understand that memcache ttl is an unix timestamp. That should be whole seconds, right?

Thanks for any help.

Federico

items.title: Docs or Python3 implementation is wrong (not sure which)
items.body:
The API states that a `get(key)` will return a string (http://pythonhosted.org/simplekv/#simplekv.KeyValueStore.get)

However the python3 section makes an ambiguous statement about all values as bytes in Python 3 (http://pythonhosted.org/simplekv/#python-3).

I understand that bytes is what is stored in the underlying stores for Py3.  However, based on the published API - it should be decoding that back to a string when it returns it to the caller.

I am not sure what your intention was with Python3 support.  So either the docs need to be updated to make it clear that the return value of a `get(key)` in Python3 is bytes.  Or the code needs to be updated to decode the result when it returns it.

I am using an upstream project (https://github.com/mbr/flask-kvsession/) which assumes the return value is a string and fails in Python3 as a result.

items.body: Could you please push a new release to PyPI? Version 0.9.2 breaks on Python 3, which seems to have been fixed after that release.

items.title: Redis keys
items.body:
From the [redis documentation](http://redis.io/topics/data-types-intro):

> Redis keys are binary safe, this means that you can use any binary sequence as a key, from a string like "foo" to the content of a JPEG file. The empty string is also a valid key.

One of the most used keys contains colon, a lot in the examples. Why do you check for valid characters here?
https://github.com/mbr/simplekv/blob/master/simplekv/__init__.py#L8

items.title: Py3k
items.body: Is there any chance to make this package available in Python 3?

items.title: Upload 0.6 package to PyPi
items.body: The current package is outdated and lacks Redis support.

items.title: Table creation fails using SQLAlchemyStore with MySQL
items.body:
SQLAlchemy with MySQL (perhaps other databases as well) [requires a length](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/types.html#sqlalchemy.types.String) specified for the String column in order to create a varchar column, but one is not specified in the table definition here:
https://github.com/mbr/simplekv/blob/master/simplekv/db/sql.py#L22

As a result, running metadata.create_all() as [suggested by the documentation](http://simplekv.readthedocs.org/en/latest/db.html) fails with:

```
sqlalchemy.exc.CompileError: (in table 'kvstore', column 'key'): VARCHAR requires a length on dialect mysql
```

This is with simplekv 0.5 and SQLAlchemy 0.7.5.

items.title: Docs need a link to the code and issue tracker
items.body:
I was reading the docs on http://readthedocs.org/docs/simplekv/en/latest/ and wanted to have a look at the code, but could not find a link. I had to use google to find this repository.

The documentation should have links (maybe on the sidebar) to the source code repository and the issue tracker.
